TOC.title: Contents

para.p: A Riemann surface is defined as a one-dimensional, connected, complex manifold []. The correct notion of an isomorphism between two Riemann surfaces is a bijection that is biholomorphic (both the mapping and its inverse are holomorphic).
As a two-dimensional real manifold, a Riemann surface is oriented.
Every Riemann surface can be triangulated.
In this definition, the “boundary” of a Riemann surface is not included in the Riemann surface. So, a Riemann surface that looks like a disk will be an open set.
Every compact Riemann surface is a closed Riemann surface of finite genus.

The set of all complex numbers
C
is itself a Riemann surface.
The upper half plane. This is an open, noncompact Riemann surface.

The Riemann sphere or
⁢ C
P 1
.

subsection.title: 1.5Definition of Teichmüller space and mapping class group

para.p:
Fix a closed Riemann surface
R
of genus
g

R

⁢ T
( R )
. The idea is to see what all surfaces we can reach from
R
by applying orientation-preserving diffeomorphisms. Let
S
be another closed Riemann surface and let
: f
→ R S
be an orientation-preserving diffeomorphism. Form the pair
( S , f )
. Take another such pair
(
S ′
, g )
. Declare
( S , f )
and
(
S ′
, g )
to be equivalent if the map
:
∘ g
f
- 1
→ S
S ′
is homotopic to a biholomorphism between
S
and
S ′
. The set of all such equivalence classes is said to be the Teichmüller space of
R
, denoted by
⁢ T
( R )
.

The Teichmüller modular group or the mapping class group of
R
is the set of all homotopy classes of orientation preserving diffeomorphisms of
R
to itself. It is denoted by
⁢ Mod
( R )
.

The moduli space of closed Riemann surfaces of genus
g
is the set of all equivalence classes of closed Riemann surfaces of genus
g
, the natural equivalence relation being the notion of biholomorphic equivalence.

para.p:
The metric is said to be in isothermal coordinates if
= μ 0

Math.text: absent = rho * (absolute-value@(w _ z)) ^ 2 * (absolute-value@(d * z + (w _ z / w _ (bar@(z))) * d * bar@(z))) ^ 2

para.p: The right hand side is the most general form of the metric. So, the question of the existence of isothermal coordinates boils down to the existence of a solution for the following PDE

Math.text: absent = q ^ (5 / 24) * ((sum _ (n element-of Z))@((6 * n + 2) * q ^ (3 * n ^ 2 + 2 * n)) / (sum _ (n element-of Z))@((4 * n + 1) * q ^ (2 * n ^ 2 + n)))

para.p: We look at the reference []. Equation (2.13) of [] provides an inner product which looks like a 2D integral and is hence manageable to get some practice with.

The wavefunctions are taken to be the factor

The formula for the inner product contains some factors that cancel the denominators of the wavefunctions, coming from the denominator of the character ().
The difference of the Theta functions in the numerator of () is such that we can combine terms to get terms of the form

This comes simply by changing variables
→ m
- m

y

Math.text: y ^ (- k * m - lambda / 2) - y ^ (k * m + lambda / 2)

para.p: In the inner product we will have to multiply two terms of this form

Math.text: (y ^ (- k * m - lambda / 2) - y ^ (k * m + lambda / 2)) * (y ^ (- k * n - lambda / 2) - y ^ (k * n + lambda / 2)) ^ *
(y ^ (- k * m - lambda / 2) - y ^ (k * m + lambda / 2)) * (y ^ (- k * n - lambda / 2) - y ^ (k * n + lambda / 2)) ^ *

para.p: Multiplying these out, we get four terms which are of the form

Math.text: y ^ alpha * y ^ * ^ beta = e ^ (2 * pi * i * (a _ x + i * a _ y) * alpha) * e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * (a _ x - i * a _ y) * beta) = e ^ (2 * pi * i * a _ x * (alpha - beta)) * e ^ (- 2 * pi * a _ y * (alpha + beta))

y ^ alpha * y ^ * ^ beta = e ^ (2 * pi * i * (a _ x + i * a _ y) * alpha) * e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * (a _ x - i * a _ y) * beta) = e ^ (2 * pi * i * a _ x * (alpha - beta)) * e ^ (- 2 * pi * a _ y * (alpha + beta))

para.p: The overall factors in the wavefunctions and the explicit factor present in (2.13) of [] combine to give us a factor

Math.text: exponential@(((pi * (k + 2)) / (4 * tau _ 2)) * (a - a ^ *) ^ 2) = exponential@(- ((pi * (k + 2)) / tau _ 2) * (a _ y) ^ 2)

The funny thing now though is that we are still left with the sum over

Actually we can fix the above problem. The point is that the

The basic message of Section 4 of the math reference [] is that the Theta functions arise by simply doing geometric quantization on the torus.

Math.text: formulae@(W _ s * ell assign exponential@(i * s * (contour-integral _ ell)@(A)), s element-of Z)

para.p:
In the book “Differential Geometry” by Loring W. Tu, on page 80 they define the set of connection one forms
ω i
j
. This means that for each
i
and
j
, we have a one form
ω i
j
. We introduce a frame
e i
, which is a collection of sections of a vector bundle forming a basis for the fiber.

We are interested in the case where the relevant vector bundle is the tangent bundle and the sections are vector fields. Thus, for each
i
, we will have a vector field
e i
. Let
X
be another vector field. Then the main definition is

Math.text: (nabla _ X)@(e _ j) = (omega ^ i) _ j * X * e _ i
(nabla _ X)@(e _ j) = (omega ^ i) _ j * X * e _ i

para.p:
The curvature two-forms
Ω i
j
, using the notation of the book “Differential Geometry” by Loring W. Tu, on page 80, are given by

Math.text: (Omega ^ i) _ j = (d * (omega ^ i) _ j + (omega ^ i) _ k) and (omega ^ k) _ j
(Omega ^ i) _ j = (d * (omega ^ i) _ j + (omega ^ i) _ k) and (omega ^ k) _ j

para.p: We pick an orthonormal frame, just because it is easy to do so.

Math.text: formulae@(e _ 1 = partial-differential _ theta, e _ 2 = (1 / sine@(theta)) * partial-differential _ phi)
formulae@(e _ 1 = partial-differential _ theta, e _ 2 = (1 / sine@(theta)) * partial-differential _ phi)

para.p:
Taking the covariant derivatives of
e 1
we get

Math.text: cotangent@(theta) * partial-differential _ phi = (nabla _ phi)@(e _ 1) = (omega ^ 1) _ (1 * phi) * e _ 1 + (omega ^ 2) _ (1 * phi) * e _ 2

para.p:
Taking the covariant derivatives of
e 2
we get

Math.text: - cosine@(theta) * partial-differential _ theta = (nabla _ phi)@(e _ 2) = (omega ^ 1) _ (2 * phi) * e _ 1 + (omega ^ 2) _ (2 * phi) * e _ 2

para.p:
Now let us try to see what the vielbein one forms look like. We denote them by
E 1
and
E 2
.

Math.text: formulae@(E _ 1 = d * theta, E _ 2 = sine@(theta * d * phi))
formulae@(E _ 1 = d * theta, E _ 2 = sine@(theta * d * phi))

para.p: Now we should check the no-torsion conditions

In this equation all terms are zero. The last term is zero since
ω 2
1
and
E 2
are both proportional to
⁢ d ϕ
and hence their wedge product vanishes. The second no-torsion condition is

Math.text: (((cosine@(theta * d * theta) and d * phi) - - cosine@(theta * d * phi)) and d * theta) - 0 = list@(0, ✓)
(((cosine@(theta * d * theta) and d * phi) - - cosine@(theta * d * phi)) and d * theta) - 0
(Omega ^ i) _ j = (d * (omega ^ i) _ j + (omega ^ i) _ k) and (omega ^ k) _ j
absent = (d * (omega ^ i) _ j + (omega ^ i) _ k) and (omega ^ k) _ j
(Omega ^ 1) _ 2 = (((d * (omega ^ 1) _ 2 + (omega ^ 1) _ 1) and (omega ^ 1) _ 2) + (omega ^ 1) _ 2) and (omega ^ 2) _ 2 = sine@(theta * d * theta) and d * phi
absent = (((d * (omega ^ 1) _ 2 + (omega ^ 1) _ 1) and (omega ^ 1) _ 2) + (omega ^ 1) _ 2) and (omega ^ 2) _ 2 = sine@(theta * d * theta) and d * phi
(Omega ^ 2) _ 1 = (((d * (omega ^ 2) _ 1 + (omega ^ 2) _ 1) and (omega ^ 1) _ 1) + (omega ^ 2) _ 2) and (omega ^ 2) _ 1 = (- sine@(theta * d * theta)) and d * phi
absent = (((d * (omega ^ 2) _ 1 + (omega ^ 2) _ 1) and (omega ^ 1) _ 1) + (omega ^ 2) _ 2) and (omega ^ 2) _ 1 = (- sine@(theta * d * theta)) and d * phi

para.p: So we see that there is only one non-trivial connection one form and it is nothing but the vector potential that one would use for a monopole field. And there is only one non-trivial curvature two form and that is nothing but the volume form which is also the field strength of the monopole.

We take the metric
+
⁢ d
x 2

y 2
y 2
. The vector fields are

Math.text: formulae@(e _ 1 = y * partial-differential _ x, e _ 2 = y * partial-differential _ y)
formulae@(e _ 1 = y * partial-differential _ x, e _ 2 = y * partial-differential _ y)

para.p: Taking the covariant derivatives we get

Math.text: partial-differential _ y = (nabla _ x)@(e _ 1) = (omega ^ 1) _ (1 * x) * e _ 1 + (omega ^ 2) _ (1 * x) * e _ 2
- partial-differential _ x = (nabla _ x)@(e _ 2) = (omega ^ 1) _ (2 * x) * e _ 1 + (omega ^ 2) _ (2 * x) * e _ 2

para.p: Now for the one forms

Math.text: formulae@(E _ 1 = (d * x) / y, E _ 2 = (d * y) / y)

As in the sphere case all the connection one forms are either zero or propotional to the same differential
⁢ d x

para.p: The Euclidean continuation of this seems to have finite beta, but that is a mirage since the spatial circle is noncompact. So this can also be called the planar BTZ black hole and really has zero beta, or infinite temperature.

paragraph.title: Lorentzian BTZ metric and the Euclidean continuation.

para.p: The Lorentzian BTZ black hole metric (non-rotating) is

Math.text: list@(d * s ^ 2 = (- d * t ^ 2 * ((r ^ 2 - R ^ 2) / ell ^ 2)) + d * r ^ 2 * (ell ^ 2 / (r ^ 2 - R ^ 2)) + r ^ 2 * d * phi ^ 2, phi) element-of closed-open-interval@(0, 2 * pi)

formulae@(beta = (2 * pi * ell ^ 2) / R, E = R ^ 2 / (8 * G * ell ^ 2))
formulae@(beta = (2 * pi * ell ^ 2) / R, E = R ^ 2 / (8 * G * ell ^ 2))

para.p:
The black hole with
= R 0
is called the zero-mass BTZ black hole. The Euclidean continuation of the metric is

Math.text: d * s ^ 2 approximately-equals r ^ 2 * ((d * tau ^ 2) / ell ^ 2 + d * phi ^ 2) + d * r ^ 2 * (ell ^ 2 / r ^ 2)
absent approximately-equals r ^ 2 * ((d * tau ^ 2) / ell ^ 2 + d * phi ^ 2) + d * r ^ 2 * (ell ^ 2 / r ^ 2)

para.p: We record the relation

Math.text: [period contractible] / [period non contractible] = beta / ell / (2 * pi) = ell / R
[period contractible] / [period non contractible] = beta / ell / (2 * pi) = ell / R

para.p:
We can also make a change of variables

⁢ R
cosh
ρ ℓ

and we get the metric

Math.text: list@(d * s ^ 2 = d * tau ^ 2 * (R ^ 2 / ell ^ 2) * (hyperbolic-sine@(rho / ell)) ^ 2 + d * rho ^ 2 + R ^ 2 * (hyperbolic-cosine@(rho / ell)) ^ 2 * d * phi ^ 2, [BTZ])

paragraph.title: Euclidean BTZ metric in upper half space variables.

para.p:
The Euclidean metric on the upper half space model of
H 3
is

Math.text: d * s ^ 2 = ell ^ 2 * ((d * x ^ 2 + d * y ^ 2 + d * z ^ 2) / z ^ 2) = ell ^ 2 * ((d * r ^ 2 + r ^ 2 * d * theta ^ 2 + r ^ 2 * (sine ^ 2)@(theta * d * phi ^ 2)) / (r ^ 2 * (cosine ^ 2)@(theta)))
absent = ell ^ 2 * ((d * x ^ 2 + d * y ^ 2 + d * z ^ 2) / z ^ 2) = ell ^ 2 * ((d * r ^ 2 + r ^ 2 * d * theta ^ 2 + r ^ 2 * (sine ^ 2)@(theta * d * phi ^ 2)) / (r ^ 2 * (cosine ^ 2)@(theta)))

para.p:
To make a BTZ black hole we identify
≡
( x , y , z )
(
⁢ λ x
,
